G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may revise and alter a judgment concerning the care, custody, and maintenance of minor children “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson (“Mother”), and respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the court’s continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters, and states as follows:

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the parties and subject matter of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 215, § 6; and applicable provisions of G.L. c. 209C, because the original custody/parenting order was entered by this Court, the parties and Children reside in Massachusetts, and the Court retains continuing jurisdiction over issues of custody and parenting time.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: At the time the 2022 Order was entered, the Court determined that the provisions of that Order were in the best interests of the Children, consistent with G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related case law.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10 & 20.proposition: Massachusetts statutes direct the Court to consider the best interests of the child as the overriding concern in custody matters.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for *custody or parenting* order modification requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) that the modification be in the child’s best interests. Schuler is an alimony and child support modification case under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 37; it discusses material change in circumstances and ability to pay, not custody or parenting time or the explicit ‘best interests of the child’ test for modifying custody. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific custody/parenting modification standard cited.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28…”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support modification case; it does not articulate the general standard for modifying a custody or parenting order as requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances and (2) best interests of the child. The discussion of modification focuses on removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 (the Yannas real-advantage/best-interests framework) and on child support under the Guidelines and G.L. c. 208, § 28, not on the general custody/parenting-time modification standard. Thus it does not serve as authority for the proposition cited.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: On July 10, 2012, the mother filed a complaint for modification alleging, as a change in circumstances, that she was to be married on August 3, 2012, to a resident of Danville, California. For this reason, the complaint sought removal of the minor children to California. ... The judge properly considered the complaint to be one for removal pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30. See Tammaro v. O’Brien, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 254, 257-259 (2010).

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: This case deals with an initial divorce judgment involving custody and removal of the children to Greece, not with a post‑judgment modification of an existing custody or parenting order. The opinion analyzes best interests of the child and the removal statute, but it does not articulate or apply the two‑part standard requiring (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment and (2) that the modification be in the child’s best interests. Therefore it does not support the specific modification-standard proposition cited.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815)…”}

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: This case is not a custody‑modification decision; it is an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). The court explicitly declines to apply or discuss the “substantial [or material] change in circumstances” standard that governs modification proceedings under G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and instead analyzes only the ‘best interests of the child’ standard for initial awards. Thus, it does not establish or affirm the two‑prong modification test described in the proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.case_name: N-Tek Construction Services, Inc. v. Hartford Fire Insurance Co.
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The case is a public construction/payment bond dispute under G.L. c. 149, § 29, not a family law or custody matter. The opinion addresses statutory notice requirements for bond claims and suretyship principles, and nowhere discusses custody, parenting plans, modification standards, or the best interests of the child. It therefore does not provide any authority for the stated proposition regarding modification of custody or parenting orders.
*Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: Section 29, which has long-standing antecedents, is a remedial law intended to protect laborers and material suppliers from nonpayment by contractors and subcontractors involved in the construction or repair of public buildings and public works. … A person who has furnished labor or materials for public works and who has not been fully paid has a right under § 29 to seek recovery under the bond of the general contractor in satisfaction of amounts justly due.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody/parenting-time modification standard case. While it discusses best interests and notes that relocation can be a substantial change in circumstances (via the ALI Principles), the SJC does not state or apply the familiar two-part Massachusetts modification test (material and substantial change plus best interests). The standard described in the proposition is neither articulated nor relied on as the governing rule in Mason v. Coleman.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] …
“(4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests … .”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings on domestic violence, not the standard for modifying an existing custody or parenting order. Nowhere does the court articulate the two-part "material and substantial change in circumstances" plus "best interests" test that governs modification proceedings. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the modification proposition for which it is cited.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly quotes and applies G. L. c. 208, § 28, stating that a custody judgment may be modified only if there has been a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and the modification is “necessary in the best interests of the children.” The court then uses that standard to evaluate whether the mother’s remarriage constitutes such a change, thereby directly affirming the two-part modification test summarized in the proposition.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 (‘Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”}

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for *modification* of an existing custody or parenting order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests of the child. Rolde v. Rolde is a direct appeal from an initial divorce judgment awarding custody; the opinion discusses the best-interests standard and joint vs. sole custody but does not address modification, changed circumstances, or the standard for altering a prior custody/parenting judgment. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific two-part modification test stated in the proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future…’”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have held that a custody or parenting order may be modified where there has been (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) a showing that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.:
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurring opinion focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and relocation/removal issues, not on the standard for modification of an existing custody or parenting order. It does not articulate or apply the two‑part ‘material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests’ test for modification, so it cannot properly be cited as authority for that general modification standard. Any reference to best interests here is in the context of relocation and initial custody/visitation, not modification of a prior judgment.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ('If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...').

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843\u201.proposition: In assessing best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors, the emotional ties between the children and each parent, the parents’ ability to cooperate and communicate regarding major decisions affecting the children, and each parent’s willingness and ability to foster the children’s relationship with the other parent. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843–44; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–97; G.L. c. 208, § 31.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595\u2.proposition: In assessing best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors, the emotional ties between the children and each parent, the parents’ ability to cooperate and communicate regarding major decisions affecting the children, and each parent’s willingness and ability to foster the children’s relationship with the other parent. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843–44; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. at 595–97; G.L. c. 208, § 31.

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. a.raw_text: *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. at 871–72
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. a.proposition: The Appeals Court has recognized that persistent, negative, and disparaging comments by one parent about the other, made in the presence of a child, can be contrary to the child’s best interests and may support modification of custody or parenting arrangements. See *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. at 871–72; see also *Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. App. Ct. at 191–92.

*Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. App. Ct. at 191\.proposition: The Appeals Court has recognized that persistent, negative, and disparaging comments by one parent about the other, made in the presence of a child, can be contrary to the child’s best interests and may support modification of custody or parenting arrangements. See *Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. at 871–72; see also *Rosenwasser*, 89 Mass. App. Ct. at 191–92.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184\u20.proposition: Where the evidence shows that the parties’ inability to cooperate in exercising joint legal custody is causing stress for the children and undermining their welfare, the Court may modify the custody arrangement, including by allocating primary decision‑making authority to one parent or adjusting the parenting schedule to reduce conflict. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184–87; *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 152–54.

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at.raw_text: *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 152–54
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at.proposition: Where the evidence shows that the parties’ inability to cooperate in exercising joint legal custody is causing stress for the children and undermining their welfare, the Court may modify the custody arrangement, including by allocating primary decision‑making authority to one parent or adjusting the parenting schedule to reduce conflict. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. at 184–87; *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 152–54.
